problems.question: Find the odd one out!
problems.hint: 3 options are intermolecular forces, while the other one isn't.
problems.detailed: Covalent bonds are strong bonds in which atoms share electrons, being the foundation of molecular compounds. The other 3 options are weak intermolecular forces.
problems.author: Alex Jicu

problems.question: We can say about dipole-dipole forces:
options: Due to quantum effects on the molecular scale, they are of the unexpected orientation (similar charges attract)
They are relatively strong in the \(CH_4\) molecules
In diatomic molecules, their strength increases as the electronegativity difference increases
They appear between a polar molecule and a non-polar molecule.
problems.hint: Dipole-dipole attractions are electrostatic forces between atoms of polar molecules.
problems.detailed: The first option is false, partially negative (\(-\delta\)) atoms are attracted by partially positive (\(+\delta\)) atoms. The electronegativities of carbon and hydrogen are relatively close to each other, with hydrocarbons being notoriously non-polar, making the second option false. The third option is true - larger electronegativity difference leads to large dipole moments, larger partial charges and larger electrostatic forces. The fourth option is false because non-polar molecules do not have charged poles and electrostatic forces appear between two charges, not an charged particle and an uncharged one.
problems.author: Alex Jicu

problems.question: The picture depicts intermolecular forces in an aqueous solution containing chloride ions. Choose the correct option.
options: The forces depicted by the dotted lines are hydrogen bonds
The forces depicted by the solid lines are weaker than those depicted by the dotted lines
The forces depicted by the solid lines involve both the hydrogen and the oxygen atoms of water
The forces depicted by the dotted lines are between the chloride ions and the oxygen atoms of water
problems.hint: Dotted lines depict ion-dipole forces and solid lines depict hydrogen bonds.
problems.detailed:
Dotted lines depict ion-dipole forces and solid lines depict hydrogen bonds. Only fluorine, oxyegn and nitrogen are electronegative enough to form hydrogen bonds.
The solid hydrogen bonds are the strongest intermolecular forces, so stronger than the ion-dipole interactions depicted by the dotted lines.
The hydrogen bonds between the water molecules form between a hydrogen atom of a molecule and the oxygen atom of another molecule, so the third option is correct.
The ion-dipole forces are formed between the negative chloride ion and the positive H pole of the water molecule.
problems.author: Alex Jicu

problems.question: Which of the following forces can exist?
problems.hint: Think about why each force arises and if the species in the given pairs have the required properties to present these forces.
problems.detailed:
Induction forces appear when a polar molecule/ion induces a dipole in a non-polar molecule. Since the \(Ne - Ne\) pair contains no charged species, induction forces cannot appear.
Dispersion forces appear between any molecules, so the \(CO_2 - CO_2\) pair will have them.
Hydrogen bonds are formed only by molecules containing F, N and O, because: the negative pole has to be negative enough; the positive pole (the hydrogen atom) has to be positive enough, so bonded to a very electronegative atom.
Since \(Br^-\) is an ion, the \(H_2O - Br^-\) force is an ion-dipole force, not a dipole-dipole force.
problems.author: Alex Jicu

problems.question: Which option shows the correct relationship between the strength of chemical forces?
problems.hint: All intermolecular forces can eventually be compared to electrostatic forces. Think in which case the electrostatic forces are stronger.
problems.detailed:
Since electrostatic forces increase with the magnitude of the charges, ion-dipole forces (between a full ionic charge and a partial charge) are stronger than dipole-dipole forces (between two partial charges).
Although hydrogen bonds are the strongest intermolecular forces, they are still much weaker than covalent bonds, by a factor of around 30.
Although induction forces are dipole-dipole forces, one of the dipoles is induced in a non-polar molecule and very small in magnitude, making the force much weaker than a tipical dipole-dipole force between two polar molecules.
Not only are dispersion forces intermolecular forces, which are much weaker than covalent bonds), but they are towards the weaker side of the intermolecular forces.
problems.author: Alex Jicu
